author: protolambda
content: This new channel is to share educational resources on Eth2, and collaborate on new resources.

author: protolambda
content:
Twitter thread with lots of good Eth2 resources: https://twitter.com/dannyryan/status/1217823276652613632?s=20
The main aggregate educational resource: https://eth2.info

author: protolambda
content: And a new initiative, to collaborate on here: a write-up that covers eth2, but from a client point of view. Networking, sync, database choices, api, etc. included.

author: protolambda
content: Starting off with a minimal hackmd to set up some direction tomorrow.

author: protolambda
content: And thank you <@!570268431522201601> and <@!478543974156730369> for offering your help with this. Others are welcome to help too. Client design is interesting, if not more than just the spec, and compiling a client-resource should help a lot of people understand/contribute

author: mratsim
content: Hackmd sounds good, once we have more flesh we can migrate it to Github, for example: https://github.com/eth2-clients

author: mratsim
content: or maybe eth2-docs (I think there is one right)

author: protolambda
content: Yes, there's this resource with a lot of diagrams and state-transition details. https://github.com/protolambda/eth2-docs But don't think that's the right place for a client-write-up. Eth2-clients repo will work. Maybe make it a static site, if it outgrows a single document.

author: leobago
content: Yes, I think it would be beneficial to have a document that compiles all that information in a self-contained fashion

author: leobago
content: it would also be good to think of it like a "school class" where the difficulty increases by chapters and even a person with zero coding skill could understand at least the first chapter
